events.originalText: The International Court of Justice ruled that Chile was under no obligation to restore Bolivia's access to the Pacific Ocean, which it had lost in the 19th century.
events.subtitle: International Court of Justice
events.headline: International Court of Justice rules in favor of Chile in Bolivia access dispute

events.originalText: Stephen Paddock fired more than 1,000 rounds of ammunition from his hotel suite on a crowd attending the Route 91 Harvest music festival on the Las Vegas Strip, resulting in 60 deaths and 867 injuries.
events.subtitle: Stephen Paddock
events.headline: Stephen Paddock's Las Vegas shooting results in 60 deaths and 867 injuries

events.originalText: A ferry collision off Lamma Island, Hong Kong, killed 39 people and injured 92 others.
events.subtitle: 2012 Lamma Island ferry collision
events.headline: Ferry collision off Lamma Island, Hong Kong, kills 39 and injures 92

events.originalText: A levy was imposed on the hiring of foreign domestic helpers in Hong Kong, who numbered in the hundreds of thousands at the time.
events.subtitle: Foreign domestic helpers in Hong Kong
events.headline: Levy imposed on hiring foreign domestic helpers in Hong Kong

events.originalText: Europol, the EU's law enforcement agency, was formed with the ratification of the Europol Convention by all member states.
events.subtitle: Europol
events.headline: Europol formed with ratification of Europol Convention by EU member states

events.originalText: A tribunal was established to consider matters relating to the constitution of Singapore upon referral by the president.
events.subtitle: Constitution of the Republic of Singapore Tribunal
events.headline: Tribunal established for constitution matters in Singapore

events.originalText: Croatian War of Independence: Yugoslav People's Army forces invaded the area surrounding Dubrovnik, Croatia, beginning a seven-month siege of the city.
events.subtitle: Croatian War of Independence
events.headline: Yugoslav forces invade Dubrovnik, Croatia, starting siege

events.originalText: Civil unions between same-sex couples were legalised in Denmark, the first country to do so.
events.subtitle: Civil union
events.headline: Denmark legalizes civil unions for same-sex couples

events.originalText: The Free Speech Movement was launched at the University of California, Berkeley, when a crowd of 3,000 students prevented police from transporting Jack Weinberg away after his arrest.
events.subtitle: Free Speech Movement
events.headline: Free Speech Movement launched at University of California, Berkeley

events.originalText: Chinese Communist Party chairman Mao Zedong publicly proclaimed the establishment of the People's Republic of China in Beijing's Tiananmen Square.
events.subtitle: Chinese Communist Party
events.headline: Mao Zedong proclaims establishment of People's Republic of China

events.originalText: The first section of the Pennsylvania Turnpike, one of the first long-distance limited-access highways in the U.S., opened to traffic.
events.subtitle: Pennsylvania Turnpike
events.headline: Pennsylvania Turnpike's first section opens to traffic

events.originalText: First World War: British and Arab troops captured Damascus from the Ottoman Empire.
events.subtitle: World War I
events.headline: British and Arab troops capture Damascus from Ottoman Empire

events.originalText: A deputation of Muslim leaders led by the Aga Khan III met Indian viceroy Lord Minto to secure greater political representation, eventually leading to the founding of the All-India Muslim League.
events.subtitle: Simla Deputation
events.headline: Aga Khan III leads Muslim leaders to meet Indian viceroy for political representation

events.originalText: Stanford University, founded by railroad magnate and California governor Leland Stanford and his wife Jane on former farm lands in Palo Alto, California, admitted its first students.
events.subtitle: Stanford University
events.headline: Stanford University admits first students in Palo Alto, California

events.originalText: At the encouragement of preservationist John Muir and writer Robert Underwood Johnson, the U.S. Congress established Yosemite National Park (pictured) in California.
events.subtitle: John Muir
events.headline: Yosemite National Park established by U.S. Congress in California

events.originalText: The first issue of National Geographic was published for the cost of fifty cents (USD), with an introductory address by the President of the magazine, Gardiner G. Hubbard.
events.subtitle: National Geographic
events.headline: First issue of National Geographic published with introductory address by Gardiner G. Hubbard

events.originalText: St Pancras railway station (pictured) in London, now the terminus of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link, opened to the public.
events.subtitle: St Pancras railway station
events.headline: St Pancras railway station in London opens to the public

events.originalText: The first political gathering of colonists (president pictured) in Mexican Texas convened to seek reforms from the Mexican government.
events.subtitle: Convention of 1832
events.headline: First political gathering in Mexican Texas seeks reforms from Mexican government

events.originalText: With the signing of the Third Treaty of San Ildefonso, Spain returned the colonial territory of Louisiana to France in return for territories in the Italian region of Tuscany.
events.subtitle: Third Treaty of San Ildefonso
events.headline: Spain returns Louisiana to France in Third Treaty of San Ildefonso

events.originalText: The Wonderful Parliament met at Westminster Abbey to address King Richard II's need for money, but soon changed focus to the reform of his administration.
events.subtitle: Wonderful Parliament
events.headline: Wonderful Parliament meets at Westminster Abbey to address King Richard II's administration

events.originalText: Edgar ascended to the English throne upon the death of his brother Eadwig.
events.subtitle: Edgar, King of England
events.headline: Edgar ascends to English throne upon death of brother Eadwig
